li.p: a line segment between two points with an assigned direction from one of the points to the other

remark.p: We usually visualize a directed line segment as an arrow.

title.term: initial point (of a directed line segment)

li.p: the first point in a directed line segment (at the tail of the arrow)

title.term: terminal point (of a directed line segment)

li.p: the second point in a directed line segment (at the head of the arrow)
the list of the changes in coordinates between initial point and terminal point
the ordered collection of components of a directed line segment

ul.li: We won't make too much of a fuss about the technical definition of a vector, especially since we will vastly increase the number of things we allow ourselves to call vector in .
Notationally, we will typeset variables representing vectors in boldface, just as we did previously for column vectors in the context of matrices and systems of equations.

li.p: a vector with two components \uvec{v} = (v_1,v_2), corresponding to a directed line segment in the plane
a vector with three components \uvec{v} = (v_1,v_2,v_3), corresponding to a directed line segment in space
the collection of all two-dimensional vectors
the collection of all three-dimensional vectors
the collection of all n-dimensional vectors

remark.p: We refer to \R^2 as two-dimensional space because, just like a map, the plane has two sets of directions north/south and east/west. We refer to \R^3 as three-dimensional space because we still have the north/south and east/west sets of directions in the xy-plane, but we add a third set of directions of up/down along the z-axis. In analogy with this, we refer to \R^4 as four-dimensional space, \R^5 as five-dimensional space, and so on.

aside.title: A look ahead
aside.p: In , we will make the concept of dimension of a vector space more precise.

title.term: vector addition (of vectors \uvec{u} and \uvec{v} of the same dimension)

li.p: given a directed line segment corresponding to \uvec{u}, create a directed line segment corresponding to \uvec{v} with initial point at the terminal point for the segment for \uvec{u}, and then the sum vector \uvec{u}+\uvec{v} corresponds to the directed line segment from the initial point for \uvec{u} to the terminal point for \uvec{v}

aside.title: See
aside.p: for some diagrams to help you visualize vector addition, similarly to how we explored vector addition through diagrams in .

li.p: given a directed line segment for \uvec{v}, the negative vector -\uvec{v} corresponds to the same segment but in the opposite direction
the result of adding a vector \uvec{u} to the negative of another \uvec{v}: \uvec{u} - \uvec{v} = \uvec{u} + (-\uvec{v})

title.term: scalar multiple (of a vector \uvec{v} by scalar k)

li.p: given a directed line segment for \uvec{v}, the scalar multiple k\uvec{v} corresponds to the directed line segment that has the same initial point and changes position in the same direction, but whose length has been scaled so that the terminal point is \abs{k} times as far from the initial point as the terminal point for \uvec{u}; if k is negative then the terminal point is also moved to the other side of the initial point

li.p: nonzero vectors that are scalar multiples of one another
a sum of scalar multiples of the vectors: k_1\uvec{v}_1 + k_2\uvec{v}_2 + \dotsc + k_m\uvec{v}_m

remark.p: In physics, it is common to use \uvec{i} and \uvec{j} to mean \uvec{e}_1 and \uvec{e}_2 in the plane, and to use \uvec{i}, \uvec{j}, and \uvec{k} to mean \uvec{e}_1, \uvec{e}_2, and \uvec{e}_3 in space. However, this alphabetic naming scheme would have to wrap back around to \uvec{a} in 19 dimensions, and in 27 dimensions there wouldn't be enough letters in the alphabet. So we will (mostly) stick with the \uvec{e}_1,\uvec{e}_2,\dotsc,\uvec{e}_n naming scheme.
